I’m way too lazy to do this the correct way as I normally do. So this is going to be a very casual blog post that I am going to write for this. So the first, let’s break down the options alloted to me on the goodjudgment open and then we can go from there. Cool? Cool.  And as a side note, all units of money are relative to a single ounce of gold. As a side note sidenote, i’m going to put the base rate with each of the sections and split up the probabilities accordingly. And I know literally not one thing about gold.  Okay, let’s jump right in.  Currently, as I am writing this blog post, the price of gold is at $1249.65. So from the jump we can look at the two most likely categories (1200 to 1250)<Gold<=(1250 to 1300). Oh, and the next thing that I need to do is think about the due date of this, which is December 28th.  Okay, okay okay. 
Less than $1,150/ounce: 
Baserate: 0% Between $1,150/ounce and $1,200 inclusive
Baserate: 11% More than $1,200 but less than $1,250: 
Baserate: 53%
Okay, what would it take for the price of gold to jump out of this category. So when does the price of gold rise. And jump into the category that is directly below of $1250 and $1300 dollars. Or let’s go back to step one of gold mining. Being supply and demand. What would make the supply of gold go down.  Actually, scratch that thought. On Monday, the price of Gold in the US hit a five month high at $1250/oz. Here’s the deal yall, I generally don’t trust spikes and don’t follow them as a law. So as the first conclusion, this category is going to be ranked as the most likely. But the next thing is, when i was writing this the first time, the price of Gold was at $1249.65. That is only $0.3 6 cents from the category below. As a result. I am downgrading this category by 6% to a solid 48%, and I am going to upgrade the other category up by 5%. Okay, let’s consider something else, the thing that would directly influence the price of gold could possibly be a recession of some sort. Or any other volitale events before the end of the year. 
Final Probability: 48% Between $1250 and $1300 inclusive 
Baserate: 33% So to start off let’s add the 5% to this probability to this category. To make it a solid 38% percent. To me, and maybe i’m crazy, the price dropping below 1200 dollars by decemeber 28 is a little crazy to me. I’m going to leave everything right here  More than $1300
Baserate: 3%

Since 1973 Gold and USD index has had - .2 correlation and -.4 for 2018, both stat. significant. The price of Gold and real interest rates have historically had a -.7 correlation, and real interest rates are on the rise. So, the question feels like...what will happen to the dollar (in the short term), what will have to real interest rates (more of a mid to long-term issue) and will there be any more high vol events before the end of the year, which is hard to predict. For 2018, Gold has had an annualized Standard Deviation of 9-10% and with estimated 15 trading days left out of 252 I put the estimated standard deviation over the rest of the year at 2.3%.

The price of gold is largely determined by the money supply. Over time, the purchasing power of gold has stayed relatively constant, with fluctuations when the economy or monetary supply is less stable, such as during the 2008 recession when gold value increased. In the next two weeks, it's unlikely that the economy will fluctuate to the extent necessary for it to leave the 1,200-1,250 range. Today, (Dec. 4th) the value of an ounce of gold is 1,236 and has been increasing for the past week. It has been in the 1,200-1,250 range for the past month, with the exception of a few days in November when it dipped slightly below 1,200. This all suggests that the price of gold will most likely stay between 1,200 and 1,250.  https://www.moneymetals.com/precious-metals-charts/gold-price

I assert that the closing spot price for an ounce of gold against the US dollar will be more than $1,200 but less than $1,250. The current spot price (Nov. 29; 12:30am) is  $1,224.30 (https://www.kitco.com/gold-price-today-usa/). Trends provided by USA Gold (http://www.usagold.com/reference/prices/goldhistory.php) indicate that the spot price for gold has stayed between 1,200.19 and 1,233.16 during the month of November. Essentially, the spot price for an ounce of gold has not exceeded the parameters of more than $1,200 and $1,250. Moreover, if we look at the spot rate over the past year, the spot price has not been outside these parameters since mid July 2018 (https://www.bullionvault.com/gold-price-chart.do). Thus I conclude that on Dec. 28 the spot price of an ounce of gold against the US dollar with be more than $1,200 but less than $1,250.

It is my assessment that the closing spot price for an ounce of gold against the US dollar on 28 December 2018 will be more than $1,200, but less than $1,250. This analysis is grounded in my assessment of the closing spot price for an ounce of gold against the US dollar for the last five years. First, the spot price for an ounce of gold against the dollar is currently $1,220.75 as of 09:52 on 27 November 2018 (https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/XAUUSD:CUR). Second, the spot price has remained more than $1,200, but less than $1,250 since October 10, an extended period of time. Third, in the last five years, the spot price differential between the end of November and December each year has been less than $30 every year, with the price fluctuating less than $25 in the majority of years. Therefore, it is expected that the spot price for an ounce of gold against the US dollar will stabilize in December. Lastly, the futures price for an ounce of gold for February 2019 is, as of 10:02 on 27 November 2018, is 1,226.80 (https://www.marketwatch.com/investing/future/gold). Thus, there is high confidence that the spot price for an ounce of gold will stabilize between $1,200 and $1,250.

Current Gold price is around $1,225~, and what will determine the future spot price will be caused the volatility of the USD. Essentially, as the world's dominant fiat currency and the largest in reserve, the need to exchange from USD to gold for most investors is usually to seek safety. From reading the historical spot price it seems there are fluctuations correspondent to world event relating to the US. For example, price around nov 6th, 2-3 days before midterm US election and the Aran sanction saw an price increase. Ofcourse Gold is also a good with its own market, namely used in electronics. Since currently the world is so chaotic with world relations sour. there is a pretty big change it might go either way, up or down.
There are only five weeks to go and I figure the value won't fluctuate that much.

Current Gold price is $1,225.80.  Six month high is slightly over $1,300.  High volatility currently leading to growth.  Just waiting on a bad economic event to move toward $1,300 but over that number is unlikely

Gold spot prices have stayed within a few hundred dollars for the last 5 years and peaked four years following the Great Recession. I think there is very little chance the spot rate will rise above 1300 within the month as there is some lag between market crashes and gold price rising. As there is quite a lot of volatility, there is a chance there will be rush into US treasuries thereby decreasing the relative spot price of gold.
Given the current volatility in the market and the raising of interest rates by the Fed, I see many risk averse investors turning to Gold to keep their money safe.

The gold market has historically softened at the end of the year, falling in December before picking up in January.  Demand for gold may be higher than the recent historic norms due to increasing volatility in global markets.

In December the Fed will do another interest rate increase.  That along with the relative strength of the U.S. economy in relation to most of the rest of the world should maintain if not strengthen the U.S. dollar.
Those reasons will push gold into the $1,150 to $1,200 range which would be a drop of more than $21 oz from the current level.
